div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,486] ALEXANDRIA, MONDAY, MAY 7, 1906. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 1 May to 31 October.
Subject to the usual 25% reduction for returning.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Monday until 4 June, and then every Tuesday. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.

The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. Combined fare to London by sea and train de luxe via Brindisi or via Marseilles £19 4.11.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt

R.M.S. “Orient" will leave Suez about May 18
R.M.S "Orontes" will leave Suez about June 1.
HOMEWARD to NAPLES, MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY.
R.M.S. "Oruba" will leave Port Said May 7
R.M.S. “Orotava" will leave Port Said May 31

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying the above reduced fares in one direction are allowed abatement of 1/3 off the full fare if return voyage be made within 4 months of arrival, or statement of 20% if return voyage be made within 6 months of arrival.
Agents. Cairo:—Thos. Cook & Son. Alexandria : —R. J. Moss & Co.—For all particulars apply
Wm. STAPLEDON & Sons, PORT SAID and PORT-TEWFIK (Suez). 30-6-908

div.head: BIBBY LINE MAIL TWIN-SCREW STEAMERS.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES MAY TO OCTOBER.
Port Said to Tilbury £ 12.15.0. and Port Said to Marseilles £ 9.0.0.
Passengers returning by the Line will be granted a rebate of 33% off the full fare i.e. Liverpool to Port Said £ 11.6.8. and Marseilles to Port Said £ 8.0.0.
OUTWARDS to COLOMBO, TUTICORIN, RANGOON. Departure from Suez.
S.S. Derbyshire 6,636 tons, May. 16.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Herefordshire 7,182 tons, May 13.
Agents– Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct returning from Suskin every Wedesday noon. Every Monday at 6 p.m a steamer leaves Suez for JEDDAH continuing every other week to SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN. Intermediate streamers do not proceed beyond Jeddah but call at Tor, (for Sinai) El Wedj and Yambo as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Menepthah now on the berth, will sail on or about Tuesday, 15 May, to be followed by S.S. Setis.

Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Passenger Tickets also issued inclusive of Railway fare through to and from Cairo. Particulars on application to
For particulars apply R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

div.p: Steamers leave SUEZ and PORT SAID fortnightly for LONDON or LIVERPOOL direct.
(Electric Light.) SALOON (Amidships) FARE £12. (Latest improvements.)
S.S. MARTABAN 7100 Tons will leave PORT SAID about May 14 for London.
S.S. AMAOAPOORA 6600 Tons will leave PORT SAID about May 23 for Liverpool.
S.S. IRRAWADDY 7300 Tons will leave PORT SAID about June 13 for Liverpool
Due in LONDON or LIVERPOOL 12 days thereafter.

G. J. GRACE & CO., ALEXANDRIA.

div.head: Russian Stream Navigation & Commercial Company.
div.p: Postal Service Accelerated
between Alexandria, Piraeus, Smyrna, Constantinople, and Odessa by the following recenlty built and perfectly equipped vessels:
Arrivals at Alexandria on Saturday afternoons.
Departures from Alexandria on Fridays at 10 a.m. Circular route between Alexandria, Port Said, the Syrian ports, Chio, Smyrna, Mount Athos, Dardanelles, Constantinople, and Odessa.
Arrivals at Alexandria every other Monday early in the morning.
Departures from Alexandria on Wednesdays at 4 p.m.
Crimean or Bessarabian table wines free.

Officially appointed & Sole Agents in Cairo to the P.&O. S.N. Co.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum.-Moderate fares.
Specially Reduced Rates for residents of Egypt by Tourist Services during November and December. First sailing November 13th.

Special Steamers and Dahabeahs for private parties.
Special arrangements for tour in PALESTINE, SYRIA and the DESERT; Lowest rates.
Best camp equipment in the country.

div.head: Austrian Lloyd’s Steam Navigation
div.p: Alexandria-Brindisi-Trieste (Venice).

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday 5 a.m. in time for express to Milan, Lucerne, Paris, Vienna, Berlin, and London, leaving Brindisi 7 a.m. Arrival Trieste Wednesday about 11 a.m. in connection with Train de Luxe Trieste-Vienna-Ostende. Passengers reach London every Friday 4.50 p.m.

div.head: SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS.
div.p: CAIRO-KHARTOUM MAIL SERVICE. - SUMMER TIME-TABLE 1906
Commencing from 1st of April, 1906, until further notice.

*Dining and Sleeping Cars. - During the month of April Sleeping and Dining Cars trains leave Cairo fro Luxor on Wednesdays, Mondays, and Saturdays at 6:30 p.m, and Luxor fro Cairo on Sundays, Tuesdays and Thursdays at 6.30 p.m.

From 1st of May 1906, those trains will be suppressed, but Dining and Sleeping Cars will be attached to the ordinary nigh trains from Cairo and Luxor three times a week, on the same above mentioned days.

div.head: INTERNATIONAL SLEEPING AND RESTAURANT CARS COMPANY.

row.cell: Restaurant Car runs every day between Cairo & Alexandria & vice-versa.

div.p: Car is attached to the 11.30 p.m train between Cairo and Alexandria and vice-versa every night. Supplement 30 P.T.

row.cell: Daily Entrainment Car Service between Cairo, Ismailia, Port Said & vice-versa.

div.p: Dining and Sleeping Cars are attached to the 8 p.m. train from Cairo every Monday, Wednesday, and Saturday and to the 5.30 p.m. train from Luxor every Tuesday, Thursday, and Sunday.
Railway and Sleeping Car tickets can be obtained any number of days ahead at the office of the Company in Cairo station. 1st clas tickets Cairo-Luxor P.T. 306. Sleeping P.T. 78.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: Hotel Beau-Rivage.
div.p: Ramleh-Alexandria
15 Minutes by Carriage or "Palais tram from Sidi Gaber Station.
The most charming Sea-side Residence in Egypt.
First Class Family Hotel with Every Modern Comfort.
Unique Situation on the Beach.
Lovely Garden. Lawn Tennis. Large Terrace. Electric Light. Sea Baths. Own springs. Perfect sanitary arrangements. Stables for horses and carriages.
Moderate Charges. -- Special terms for Government Officials and Officers of the Army of Occupation.
G. RUNCKEWITZ, Proprietor.

div.head: EASTERN EXCHANGE HOTEL, PORT SAID.
div.p: First Class Hotel. Modern in all respects.
Fire-proof, Drained to the Sea, Lifts, Electric Light, English and French Billiards, Fresh and Salt Water Baths.
The Coolest Summer Residence in Egypt.
Special terms to Cairo Residents and their families desirous of enjoying the cool air and sea bathing during the summer months.
Dragomans in Hotel Uniform Meet all Trains and Steamers.

div.head: NEW KHEDIVIAL HOTEL, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: First-class Hotel. Situated in Rosetta Avenue, the finest quarter in the Town. Two mintes from Railway Station. Close to Conservatory and the Opera House. Lift. Electric Light Throughout. Perfect Sanitary Arrangements. Magnificent Ball, Reception, Reading, and Music Rooms. Bar and Smoking Room.
HENRI CHAMOULLEAU, Proprietor.

div.head: The Egyptian Gazette
div.p: The English Daily Newspaper, Established 1880.
Editor and Manager - - R. SHELLING
Price: ONE PIASTRE TARIFF
MONDAY, MAY 7, 1906
LORD CROMER AND EGYPTIAN COMPANIES

Lord Cromer’s Report oovere such a vast fiold that it is impossible for us to deal with the many subjects of economics, finance, admi¬nistration, and work of the Ministries in one short article. Each reader will seek for himself the chapter which interests him most, and there are few indeed who have not some interest in one or more of the Egyptian companies. These will read with close attention what Lord Cromer has to say of the economic condition of the country as bearing on companies, present and future. The attitude of the Government towards commercial undertakings is explicitly stated. It is no function of a Government to distinguish between good and bad investments. Of that the investor must himself be the sole judge. There has been too much talk of Egyptian "booms” as if we were all being carried along on a tidal wave of prosperity to find ourselves presently stranded or dashed on the rocks. Clearly and logically Lord Cromer reviews the situation leading to the conclusion, in which he will have the support of those who best know the country, that the prosperity of Egypt is no mushroom growth which will eventuate in a reaction. We heartily welcome such a much-needed authoritative statement of the physician whose finger has been on the pulse of Egypt for a quarter of a century. Whilst this hopeful view will encourage the bona-fide investor it most not be concluded that there is no word of warning for the reckless and over-sanguine. Far from it, for it is clearly pointed oat that Egypt is an agricultural country liable to the vicissitudes of crops, markets, and plant diseases, and though in many respects less liable to these than other countries, still, entire exemption may not always be looked for. The masterly exposition of conditions in Egypt must be read in its entirety to be folly appre¬ciated, and we heartily commend a careful perusal of the chapter to all who take an interest in the country. Investors mast neither assume that all Egyptian undertakings are based on an unsounded foundation, nor must they ran to the opposite extreme of judging them all as sound concerns. "Caveat emptor” is a sound motto, and no Govern¬ment can wholly protect a fool. Egypt can absorb much capital, which can be safely and profitably employed in development of land and in other ways, bat the company promoter is as unscrupulous as he is ubiquitous. and if he mislead the unwary by garbled quotations from Lord Cromer’s Report, the victim has himself alone to blame. Encourage¬ment and warning are so blended that the timorous and unwary will find much for their guidance, and for our part we cannot see what more could have been said for their direction.

div.head: LOCAL AND GENERAL
div.p: The Plague.
To-day’s bulletin records a death at De?hna and a fatal case in the Kous district.
Mouled el Nebi.
The feast of the Prophet was celebrated at Cairo as usual with great rejoicings The Khedive presided at the fete.
Luxor Winter Palace.
The internal arrangement of this hotel will be complete on 1st January next, when the hotel will be open to receive tourists.
Alhambra.

The revne which has been running at this theatre for a fortnight has given place to a variety entertainment. This evening there will be a gala performance for the benefit of Mlle Pilar Garcia, the charming Spanish dancer.
The Tabernacle of Israel.

Mr. Jos. C. Dutton will deliver his lectures on the Tabernacle of Israel, illustrated with a large model, for the English soldiers in the Presbyterian chaplain’s meeting room at Kasr- el-Nil barracks, Cairo, on Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday, Thursday, Friday, and Saturday, 7th to 12th inst., at 7.30 p.m.
Burglary in Ramleh-boulevard.

Last night the office of Mr. Menahem Bracha, close to the, Messageries Maritimes agency, in the Ramleh boulevard, Alexandria, was burgled and the safe broken into. Eighteen Credit (3% 1886) shares and a Lot Ture were stolen, besides £50 in cash. The ghaffir has been arrested on suspicion.
National Bank of Egypt.

The National Bank of Egypt announces that scrip certificates of the last issue of 50,000 shares may be exchanged for warrants to bearer on and after April 30. Scrip must be listed on forms to be obtained of the bank, 4 and 5, King William-street, E. C., and left three dear days for examination.

Logic always finishes by imposing itself, more or less naturally, in all countries, accord¬ing to the degree of their intellectual develop¬ment. The Berlitz Schools, for the teaching of the living languages, prosper on the same principle. The remarkable success obtained during the last few years by the branches of Alexandria (12 rue Rosette) and of Cairo (1 Sharia Kamel) is one of the best proofs of the constant evolution of Egypt in the right direction. [Advt.].
Florio-Rubattino Steamer Mystery.

The usual weekly Florio Rubattino steamer from Genoa, Leghorn, Naples, and Messina, was due to arrive at Alexandria yesterday, but the steamer has not been sighted yet and no news has been received as to the vessel’s whereabouts. The Alexandrian agency sent telegrams to Italy to the head office of the com¬pany this morning asking for news and a reply is expected this afternoon.

It is certain that the steamer touched at Naples and it is believed that as there was a general strike then at that port, the steamer has been delayed If so she is expected to arrive shortly for if she had been detained per manently at Naples the agency here would have received some notification on the subject by wire from Italy.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: The statement made by some of our con-temporaries as to the approaching transfer from Mansourah to Alexandria of Judge Eeman is inexact. Judge Haloard, the Swede, has been transferred to Alexandria from Man- sourab.

We are pleased to announce the engagement of Mlle Mathilde Sursook, daughter of M. and Mme Alexander Sursock, to Marquis Don Alberto Theodoli, Italian delegate on the board of the Ottoman Public Debt.

A marriage has been arranged, and will take place at the end of June, between Mr. Samuel Gurney Sheppard, D.S.O., of Leggatts, Potters- bar, Herts, a director of the Aboukir Company, and Eileen Mary Winchester, daughter Of the late Mr. Winchester Clowes, J.P., of Hitchin, Herts.

Among the latest arrivals at the Eastern Exchange Hotel, Port Said, are Mr. and Mme. Colombani, Miles Colombani, Mr. and Mme. Tartarini and family, Mme. and Miles Dominici, Mr. L Labrosse, Mr. Lepenuen Mr. and Mrs. Scorer, Mr. and Mrs. Tanner, Mr. Ed. Kirby, Mr. Boyd Carpenter and party, Mr. and Mrs. M.C. Moss and nurse, Mr. and Mrs. P. R. Boxwell, nurse and child, Mr. and Mrs. Flood, Mr. H. W. Binning, Mr. and Mrs. W.Cople Mr. H. W. Tite, Mr. T.W. Redfern, Mr. H. Meyer, Mr. and Mrs. F. Moule, Mr. and Mrs. Hemsted, Mr. Brittain. Hunter Pacha, Mr. G. Parker, Mr. Frank Jaques, Mr. A Eeman, Mr. G. W. Hostop, Maj. Gen. H. Ramzi Pacha, Mr. M. Millian, Mr. G. H.H. Tames, Mr. B. S. Tames, Miss E. A. Dukin, Mr. H. P Dobson, Mr. T. Tunstall, Countess Mancinelli Scotti, Mr. add Mrs. Grafton, Grafton Bey.

div.head: The NATAL TROBULES
ENGAGEMENTS WITH REBELS
div.p: DURBAN, May 5.
Colonel Mackenzie’s force has entered Zulu- land, but is proceeding slowly as it is escorting a huge convoy to an unknown base.
(Reuter)
DURBAN, May 6.
Colonel Mackay, with a large force, ascended one of the highest points in the Nkandhla range, eight miles from the Magistracy, and shelled a number of kraals. Shots were ex¬changed with the rebels.
(Reuter)

div.head: BOMB OUTRAGE IN MOSCOW.
GOVERNOR GENERAL WOUNDED.
div.p: Moscow. May 6.

A bomb was thrown at the Governor-General, Admiral Dubaasoff, while he was returning from the cathedral to-day. He was wounded in the foot and his aide de-camp and a sentry were killed. His assailant, who wore officer’s uniform, is reported to have been killed.

div.head: THE DUMA.
CONSTITUTIONAL DEMOCRATS POLICY
div.p: ST. PETERSBURG, May 5.

A congress of constitutional democrats has assembled here to consider their policy in the Duma. The programme advocated by the leaders includes universal suffrage, complete amnesty, and the abolition of capital punish¬ment.
(Reuter)

div.head: CHINESE BOYCOTT OF AMERICA.
CONSIDERABLE APPREHENSION IN U. S. A.
div.p: WASHINGTON, May 5.
China has notified her intention of opening Manchurian ports and interior cities only after she has completed the preparation of regulations for the government of foreign oolonies- therein.
(Reuter)
WASHINGTON, May 6. Considerable apprehension is felt in America at the growing strength of the Chinese boycott.
(Reuter)

div.head: END OF ROYAL TOUR. RETURN OF PRINCE OF WALES.
div.p: LONDON, May 6.
The Prince and Princess of Wales, on board the Renown, have arrived at Portland. They will proceed to Spithead to-morrow.
(Reuter)

div.head: THE FRENCH ANARCHIST PLOT.
div.p: PARIS, May 6.
All the accused who were arrested in con-nection with the raids of the 27th April were released in the evening.
(Havas)

div.head: FRENCH ELECTIONS
div.p: PARIS, May 6.

The results of the elections known so far show that 150 Ministerialists and 66 of the Opposition have been elected. The results of the second ballots appear favourable to the old majority. Messrs. Millerand, Bienaime, Briand, Pelle tan, Doumergue, Leygues, Deschanel, Aynard, Doumer, Brisson, Barres, and Francois Delon- cle have been elected. Messrs. Lanessan, Mar- chand, and Deroulede are having second ballots. General Zurlinden, M. Marcel Habert, and M. Flourecs were defeated.
(Havas)

div.head: AMERICAN BATTLESHIP ASHORE.
div.p: NEW YORK, May 6.
The battleship Rhode Island is ashore in Chesapeake Bay : tugs have hitherto failed to refloat her.
(Reuter)

div.head: THE FRONTIER DISPUTE
div.p: FRANCO-RUSSIAN SUPPORT OF BRITAIN. LONDON, May 5.
Newspapers emphasize the significance of the Franco-Russian support of Great Britain on the Tabah question.
(Reuter)
CONSTANTINOPLE, May 5.
The French Ambassador has advised the Sultan to yield to the Anglo-Egyptian de mands ; the Russian Ambassador has received similar instructions.
(Reuter)
PARIS, May 5

The “Temps” learns from Constantinople that the Ambassadors Constans and Zinoview will declare to the Sultan that France and Russia advise Turkey to agree to the British demands regarding the withdrawal of the Turkish troops from the Sinai Peninsula.
MALTA, May 5.
The transport Dilwara is hourly expected passing here. She will be detained to convey the 4th Battalion of the Worcestershire Regi-ment to Alexandria.
(Reuter)
CONSTANTINOPLE, May 6.
A Court dignitary attempted to modify the attitude of the British Ambassador, but failed.
(Havas)

div.head: THE SITUATION AT RAFAH.
div.p: The situation at Rafah, near El Arish, may be summed up as follows
The Turks are encamped at a point fifty yards on the Egyptian side of the frontier, some four miles from the coast. They number 50 soldiers, with 3 officers and a tax collector.

The two pillars which have always been recognised by the people of El Arish as the boundary marks were undoubtedly removed by the Turks on the night of April 12. Owing no doubt to the fact that the frontier is populated only by Bedouins who cultivate the plain between Sheikh Zeyoud—16 miles from El Arish—and Gaza in places where water is to be found the news seems to have taken some time to reach El Arish and Cairo.
Eleven Egyptian telegraph poles have been appropriated and Turkish poles substituted.
The Sawarka Bedouins of the frontier district complain that the Turks have stolen their cattle and after driving-them away have turned their horses loose on their corn fields.

A strip of land about 800 yards in width lying between the recognised frontier line and the road running from the interior to Ain Rafeib, north of Rafah, has been registered in the Saltan’s name. It is said to prodace a good crop.

We gather that the attitude of the Turks towards-the Egyptian delegates was courteous enough, but that they absolutely refused to admit the right of Capt. Waymouth, of H.M.S. Minerva, who accompanied them, to take any part whatever in the discussion relative to the violation of the frontier, on the ground that it was a purely Egyptian concern.

The so-called German mission, which arrived at El Arish and was sent back to Gaza, was composed of Hebrews, most of them Russian subjects, who wanted to buy land at El Arish. The fact that a German Jew led the party accounts for the extraordinary and misleading stories that have been spread as to the aims of the "mission.” In our opinion the “disguised German officers” or “secret agents” were sim- ply what they declared themselves to be, viz., poor Jews looking for a good bargain in land. Henceforward the German agents must be class'd with the great gun which one of our contemporaries averred — it is true. on Bedouin evidence—to have entered Rafah behind a team of 18 horses.

Rafah is 25 miles E.N.E of El Arish and boasts a couple of good wells—Ain Rafeih and Ain Rafah. The boundary pillars, one of which bore an inscription commemorating H.H, the Khedive’s visit in 1897, have marked the frontier “min zaman,” and there seems no rea¬son to distrust the evidence of the “oldest inhabitants” cf El Arish in this particular.

div.head: THE MEDITERRANEAN FLEET.
div.p: It is stated that a number of cruisers belong-ing to the Mediterranean Fleet are off Alex-andria, within reach of communication by wireless telegraphy.

div.head: H. M. S. MINERVA.(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).
div.p: Port Said, Sunday.

H.M.S. Minerva. returned here on Friday evening from Ei Arisb, after nearly a week’s absence. I have been unable to obtain any news of what took place there, but some very wild rumours are current Yesterday afternoon the Minerva received a wireless message from outside and left immediately, and up to the time of writing has not returned.
There is a rumour that the message received by the Minerva was to the effect that there was a ship in distress outside, but whether this is the case or not, I have been unable to ascertain.

div.head: ADMIRALTY TENDERS.
div.p: The Admiralty has invited tenders for the conveyance of some 650 men and 450 horses from Southampton or Queenstown to Alex- andria for prompt embarkation.

div.head: ANOTHER TRANSPORT CHARTERED.
div.p: The Leyland liner Cestrian has been char-tered by the Government to convey troops to Egypt. The Cestrian is at present homeward bound from Boston, and her arrival in the Mersey is expected in a few days.

div.head: GHAZI MUKHTAR PACHA INTERVIEWED.
THE TURKISH STANDPOINT.
div.p: In the course of an interview with a repre-sentative of the‘‘Egyptian Gazette" this morning, H. E.Ghazi Mukhtar Pacha,the Imperial Ottoman High Commissioner, declared that the Sublime Porte agreed with Lord Fitzmaurice as regards the first part of his statement in the House of Lords on Wednesday, that “the Sinai pen¬insula did not form part of Egypt proper.” The Sublime Porte, however, could not agree with the second part of that statement, namely, that it remained under undisputed Egyptian Administration. Here the Porte differed, as Lord Fitzmaurice did not qualify that admini¬stration, which is, according to the Porte, temporary, and subject to reversion (repren- able) to Turkish administration.

The Ghazi further declared that in view of the commercial importance which would be likely to accrue to Akaba as the Red Sea terminus of the Hedjaz Railway, it would obviously not be advisable to have two different administrations so close to one another ; bat that Turkey had never entertained the least idea, which Great Britain attributed to her, of nearing the Suez Canal; all she desired was to have more elbow room for Akaba.
He was convinced of a pacific solution.
As for the report of Germany supporting Turkey, this was totally unfounded.

div.head: THE NATIVE ATTITUDE.
div.p: A correspondent writes:

It is greatly to be hoped that the expression of opinion on the part of a native notable given to your Damanhour Correspondent, and which appeared in Saturday's paper, is anything but epresentative of the feelings entertained by rthe great majority of the Egyptian native population towards the English people. But should this unfortunately be the case, it is, I think, greatly due, not as you say in your leading article to “the tactless behaviour of two or three officers, private soldiers, or tour¬ists,” but to the general want of consideration for native feelings shown by so large a number of English people. Europeans generally, I know, are quite as bad as my countrymen, but as they simply profit by British rule, without taking part in the government of the country; it is only the conduct of the English that stands BO prominently in view. “We must show them our superiority,” said a young Eng- lishman to me a few days ago, and it is this very claim of superiority that is so harmful in its effects, as well as unjust in its conception. Still it is greatly to be hoped that as a body the fellaheen, as yon remark, are “either neutral or actually friendly to the British Occupation.” Indeed it would be strange were it otherwise, for it is inconceivable that after enjoying many years of freedom from tyranny, and experienc- ingan ever-growing prosperity they would wish to go back to the old misrule—or worse. Why should they? Religions fanaticism, we are told would be the important factor, but there is certainly no reason why it should be. Even the suppression of slavery has been carried out in such a way that no interference with the Koran and its teachings has taken place, while the ill-advised action of certain missionary zealots has been promptly and effectually check-ed. A great responsibility rests at the present moment on the native Press. Certain papers have of late adopted a far more friendly at¬titude to the British Agent and Advisers, and the policy carried out by the Egyptian Go¬vernment with their help has met with more cordial support than formerly. They will render valuable service if at the present crisis they do their best to strengthen the hands of the Egyptian Government. If they do this, and Egyptian officials take the same firm stand as they did in the recent Alexandria riot, when it will be remembered there was the same sense of fear of a Mohamedan rising, we can all await the action of diplomacy in the frontier question, or in the last resort the clash of arms, without contemplating the possi- bility of so terrible an event as a collision between the Mohamedan and Christian populations.

div.head: FRENCH OPINION.
div.p: M. Andre Mevil, writing in the “Echo de Paris,” says: “It is to be expected that England will embrace this opportunity of dealing a blow to Constantinople, showing the Porte that she is always to be counted with in the East. Indirectly, too, she would thus deal a blow to German influence.

“Nor must we forget that the dispute that has arisen concerning Egypt cannot leave ns indifferent, as, according to article 9 of the Convention of April 8, 1904, the French and British Governments are under engagements to lend each other mutual support of their diplomacy for the execution of the clauses relating to Egypt and Morocco. It is certain that if there be need England will receive from ns the same support which she gave ns in the Moroccan affair. From the International point of view, the. Tatah incident, then, may have serious consequences.”

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H H. the Khedive returned from Cairo to Montazah Palace yesterday evening. His High- ness will probably leave this afternoon for Mariout.

div.head: THE ARMENIAN COMMUNITY.
AGITATION AGAINST BARTAU PACHA
IMPORTANT MEETING.
div.p: The agitation among the Armenian com-munity of Alexandria on the subject of deposing Bartau Pacha from the presidency of the community came to a head yesterday, when a mass meeting of all the representatives of the community was held at the Alhambra Theatre. The female sex had been invited to attend, and a large number of ladies put in an appearanoe. Among those present were the leading notables among the Armenians in the city, with the exception of Bartau Pacha, who of coarse refrained from attending.

Mr. Bekarian was chosen chairman, and opened the proceedings with a short speech. He declared that it was a great democratic victory, and that the deposition of the president and of the old committee was due to the united efforts of the Armenians, assisted by the good services of Mustapha Pacha Ibadi, the new Governor of Alexandria, Miralai Hopkinson Bey, Commandant of the Alex andria City Police, and Heddaya Bey, who acted in a most fair and equitable manner in this question. The chairman then asked Mr. Damadian to give a concise explanation to the meeting of the reason why it had been con- vened.

Mr. Damadian, who spoke for three-quar¬ters of an hoar, declared that the community was entirely victorious and that Bartau Pacha had been obliged to resign against his will. He described the scenes which had occurred at the church on the last three Sundays, and the interview which the Armenian representa¬tive had had with the Governor of Alexandria. He then dealt with the destruction of the tablet erected by Bartan Pacha in the church and showed that it was broken with the general consent of the community, who ob¬jected to the presence of such a tablet in their church. He proposed that a new tablet should be erected in its stead bearing the date of the destruction of the former one, with the words “Maintain the Constitution.” This proposal was greeted with great cheers and daring the entire speech Mr. Damadian was frequently applauded. He then read out an official letter received from the Bishop of Egypt, Monsignor Meguerditch Aghavnouni, addressed to the community, wherein he said that the preparations for the new elections would begin to-day (Monday). Mr. Damadian said that the action of the Bishop was very welcome but somewhat tardy.

Daring the speech a number of telegrams and letters were received from the Armenian communities at Cairo and Tantah, all strongly supporting the present policy of the colony. Mr. Damadian thanked the English advisers of the Khedivial Government for having given ear to their grievances, and ended a brilliant speech by calling on all his hearers to pull together so that the community should pre¬serve a united front to its enemies.

Three representatives of the Armenians of Alexandria were afterwards elected by acclama-tion. These were Messrs. Sbnorkian, Damadian, and Tonrohondjian. The meeting then closed, while the Armenian Band played the Khedivial March.

The agitation against Bartau Pacha began a month ago, when a lawsuit was brought against the Armenian newspaper “Azad Pen” for having given publicity to certain private actions of Bartau Pacha and Mr. Agop Onghourian. The newspaper was defend¬ed by Maitre Mercinier, who made a brilliant speech in defence. The speech was reproduced in the paper and its contents were such that an agitation was at once set on foot to depose Bartau Pacha.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL DECORATIONS.
div.p: The King has been pleased to give and grant unto the under mentioned officers his Majesty’s Royal licence and authority to accept and wear decorations (as stated against their respective names) which have been conferred upon them by bis Highness the Khedive of Egypt authorised by his Imperial Majesty the Saltan of Turkey, in recognition of valuable services rendered to his Highness:
IMPERIAL OTTOMAN ORDER OP THE MEDJIDIEH
SECOND CLASS.
Captain and Brevet Major (local Lieutenant- Colonel) George Bohun Macauley, C. M. G., Royal Engineers.
IMPERIAL OTTOMAN ORDER OF THE MEDJIDIEII,
THIRD CLASS.
Captain William Elrington Longfield, Royal Engineers.
IMPERIAL OTTOMAN ORDER OF THE MEDJIDIEII,
FOURTH CLASS.
Lieutenant Percy Calvert Lord, Royal Engieers.
IMPERIAL OTTOMAN ORDER OF THE OSMANIEH
FOURTH CLASS.
Lieutenant William Byron Drary, R. N. ; Captain Maurice Eden Sowerby, Royal Engi-neers ; and Lieutenant Stewart Francis New- combe, Royal Engineers.

The King has been pleased to give and grant onto the Honourable Anthony Ashley Ivo Pelham, Charles Martin Hickley, Esq., and Arthur Russell Windham, Eeq, of the Sudan Government Railways, his Majesty’s Royal licence and authority that they may respectively accept and wear the Insignia of the Fourth Class of the Imperial Ottoman Order of the Medjidieh, which decoration has been conferred upon them by his Highness the Khedive of Egypt, authorised by his Imperial Majesty the Sultan of Turkey, in recognition of valuable services rendered to his Highness.

div.head: PORT SAID NOTES
WHAT PORT SAID OWES TO THE CANAL
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
Port Said, Thursday.

In spite of many pessimistic prognostica¬tions, the colossal American floating dock, Admiral Dewey, got safely through the Canal, a fact which reflects great credit on the officials of the transit service of the Canal Co. It would be impossible to estimate how much Port Said owes to the company. In fact, the very existence and structure of the town and harbour are the result of the opening of the Canal.

The “foul and stagnant ditch,” founded on the earnings, according to Lord Palmerston, of "cafe waiters deceived by the newspapers lying on the tables, or grocers and dry goods assistants entrapped by the paper, in which they wrapped their wares," has proved to be a success beyond what the most sanguine may have dared to dream. In the words of Colonel Sir Howard Vincent, a town now flourishes with between 40,000 and 50,000 inhabitants, where fortunes have been made and will be made, where ships can coal quicker than any¬where else in the world; bat which “The Daily News,” with that accuracy of forecast which has always distinguished it, ridiculed as absurd—“the building of a town without money, without water, without stone.” Syn¬onymous as is the United States with every¬thing typical of modem progress, she can as yet show nothing so illustrative of the grit necessary to put through, in spite of organized and influential opposition, so great a feat of engineering. When de Lesaeps cut the first sod of the Suez Canal, he had not at his disposal the mighty machines and appliances which America will use in her latest attempt to cut through the Isthmus of Panama. Long after his detractors are forgotten, the name of Lesseps will be honoured as that of a man who was able, not only to conceive a great idea, but to carry it out.
Russian Troops.

There seems to be no end to the almost constant stream of Russian troops being re¬patriated from Vladivostock to Odessa. One of their officers who came ashore will remem¬ber with gratitude one of the officials of the Passport Office, who, after the former left the office, found a pocket-book, fall of valuable papers and a large roll of banknotes, which was promptly returned through the Russian Consul.
An Innovation.

Many people will be pleased to hear that the police have reserved to themselves the privi¬lege of granting leave to cafes to keep open all night At present the cafe mast close at two in the morning ; consequently people living in their neighbourhood will no longer be disturbed from sunset to sunrise.
Street Pests.

It is pleasing to see also that the police are more vigilant in preventing the molestation of passengers by people selling obscene photo-graphs and post cards, as well as keeping an eye on the numerous touts and shoe-blacks, whose name is legion. The supervision of the Rue de Commerce by two European police officials has done much to mitigate this nui¬sance.
The Dust Nuisance.

The provision of water-carts has considerably allayed the dust nuisance, though the roads are so far removed from what they ought to be that in places which have received an extra amount of water there is created a mud nuisance for a short time after their passing.
H.M.S. Minerva.
Yesterday evening the Minerva arrived from El-Areech, off the port. She sent ashore for letters and dispatches, and after the arrival of the Cairo train put out to sea again.
Personal.
The many friends of Mr. Mailing, British Vice Consul, will regret to hear that, owing to ill-health, it has been necessary for him to leave Port Said for a time for Europe.
We are pleased to hear that Dr. Orme, the cleaver surgeon at the Government Hospital, is making a good recovery in England.
Mr. Christian, the representative of Messrs. Wills & Co. in their contract work on the harbour extensions, has commenced his duties at Port Said.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUEZ.
div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT).
Suez, Saturday.
H. H. S. Nour el Babr sailed from Suez this afternoon for Akaba with despatches for H. M. S. Diana.
The Italian gunboat Barba Rigo arrived a few days ago at Suez from the Somali coast, and has been placed under the orders of the Italian Diplomatic Agency at Cairo.
Suez, Sunday.
H. M. S. Perseus arrived at Suez yesterday at 4 o’clock, and entered the Canal at 5.15 p.m. the same afternoon.

div.head: STEAMER MOVEMENTS
div.p: The M.M. steamer Senegal, from Marseilles, passed the Straits of Messina on Saturday, and is doe at Alexandria to-morrow.
The Ellerman S. S. Algerian sailed hence on Saturday evening for Liverpool direct with a general cargo, including 772 bales of cotton and 13, 979 bags of onions.
